required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Long-term Safety of Once-daily Hydrocodone Bitartrate (HYD) Tablets For Moderate to Severe Chronic Nonmalignant and Nonneuropathic Pain. Includes a 24-week Extension Period.
clinical_study.official_title: An Open-label, Multicenter Study to Assess the Long -Term Safety of Hydrocodone Bitartrate (HYD) Tablets 20 to 120 mg Once-daily in Subjects With Moderate to Severe Chronic Nonmalignant and Nonneuropathic Pain

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to characterize the long-term safety of Hydrocodone Bitartrate (HYD) tablets 20 to 120 mg once-daily in subjects with chronic nonmalignant and nonneuropathic pain.

primary_outcome.measure: The Number of Participants With Adverse Events as a Measure of Safety
primary_outcome.description: Safety assessments included AEs, clinical laboratory test results, vital sign measurements, ECG findings, and audiology assessments.

primary_outcome.measure: Daily "Average Pain Over the Last 24 Hours"
primary_outcome.time_frame: Core study: from start to end of maintenance period (up to 52 weeks); Extension study: from start of maintenance to end of extension (up to 76 weeks)
primary_outcome.description: "Average pain over the last 24 hours" score (on an 11-point numerical rating scale where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine).

secondary_outcome.description: "Pain right now" scores were collected using an 11-point scale where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. The "pain right now" scores were only collected during the Core Study. "Pain right now" scores were not assessed during the Extension Period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Medical Outcomes Study (MOS) Sleep Scale - Revised (MOS Sleep-R)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and up to 52 weeks in the Core Study maintenance period, and up to 24 weeks in the Extension Period
secondary_outcome.description: The MOS Sleep-R is a brief, self-administered 12-item assessment designed to measure key aspects of sleep. It includes a sleep problems index II and 6 subscale scores - sleep disturbance, sleep adequacy, daytime somnolence, snoring, awaken short of breath or with headache, and quantity of sleep. For each individual and time of assessment, quantity of sleep was recorded as the number of hours slept per night. The number of hours it took the subject to fall asleep per night was categorized 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 corresponding to 0 through 15, 16 through 30, 31 through 45, 46 through 60, or more than 60 minutes, respectively. The other scales were recorded as 1 = all of the time, 2 = most of the time, 3 = some of the time, 4 = a little of the time, or 5 = none of the time. A higher value indicates a better score, therefore a positive change from baseline indicates a better sleep pattern and a negative change from baseline indicates a worsening in sleep pattern.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 52 weeks in the Core Study maintenance period, and up to 24 weeks in the Extension Period
secondary_outcome.description: The BPI-SF assessed the severity of pain and interference of pain on daily functions. It consists of 9 sections denoted by Q1 to Q8 and Q9A to Q9G according to their order in the questionnaire, that measure pain location, intensity, pain treatment, and functional interference of pain on mood and every day activities. Scores ranged from 0 (none) to 10 (worst as can be). Four of the items (questions 3 to 6) assess severity of pain and 7 items (questions 9A to 9G) assess interference of pain. The pain interference subscale score was determined by calculating the mean of responses to Q9A - Q9G [Q9A (general activity), Q9B (mood),Q9C (walking), Q9D (working), Q9E (relations with others), Q9F (sleep), and Q9G (enjoyment of life)] and the severity of pain subscale score was determined by calculating the mean of responses to Q3 - Q6 [Q3 (worst pain in last 24 hours), Q4 (least pain in last 24 hours), Q5 (average pain), and Q6 ("pain right now")]. A lower score indicates lower pain.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 52 weeks in the Core Study maintenance period, and up to 24 weeks in the Extension Period
secondary_outcome.description: The SF-36 is a generic health survey with 36 items that measure functional health and well-being from the subject's perspective. The 36 questions are grouped into 11 sections. Some of the sections consist of multiple questions. The survey is summarized into 8 dimensions/scales: physical functioning, role physical, bodily pain, general health, vitality, social functioning, role emotional, and mental health. From the 8 health dimensions, physical component summary, and mental component summary measures are derived. Scores on each scale ranged from 0 to 100; a higher score indicates a better perception of health.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At Week 52 in the Core Study maintenance period and at Week 24 in the Extension Period
secondary_outcome.description: The PGIC is an ordinal scale of global evaluation that assesses the change in overall status relative to the start of the study. The scale has only 1 item that measures global change of overall status (improvement or worsening) by the subject on a 7-point scale (Very much improved, Much improved, Minimally improved, No change, Minimally worse, Much worse, Very much worse.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At Week 52 or upon early discontinuation at or before Week 4 in the Core Study maintenance period
secondary_outcome.description: The TSQ is a self-administered questionnaire that consists of 2 parts. Part I has 6 questions (Q1 to Q6) that ask the subject to rate the experience with use of the study drug in comparison to the prestudy pain medication regarding ease of use, convenience, frequency, pain control, and overall satisfaction. Each question was rated on a scale from 1 (extremely satisfied) to 6 (extremely dissatisfied): Q1=Satisfaction with study drug; Q2=Ease of study drug use to treat pain; Q3=Convenience of study drug to treat pain; Q4=Overall drug satisfaction managing pain; Q5=Satisfaction with frequency of use; Q6=Ease of planning study drug use. The number of subjects with each category (1-6) of response for each individual question (Q1-Q6) was summarized for subjects who entered the core study maintenance period and responded to each question. TSQ - Part I was not administered in the extension period.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At Week 52 or upon early discontinuation at or before Week 4 in maintenance and at Week 24 in extension
secondary_outcome.description: The TSQ is a self-administered questionnaire that consists of 2 parts. Part II has 2 questions that measure the subject's willingness to continue the use of study drug as pain medication (Q1), and to recommend the study drug to someone else (Q2). Question 1 consists of 6 categories of response rated on a scale from 1 (very willing to continue) to 6 (very unwilling to continue): 1=Very willing to continue; 2=Willing to continue; 3=Somewhat willing to continue; 4=Somewhat unwilling to continue; 5=Unwilling to continue; 6=Very unwilling to continue. Question 2 consists of 3 categories of response: 1=yes; 2=no; 3=undecided. The number of subjects with each category of response for each individual question was summarized for subjects completing the core study maintenance period and for those enrolled in the extension period.

intervention.description: Hydrocodone bitartrate q24h film-coated tablets 20 - 120 mg once daily

facility.name: Quality of Life Medical & Research Center, LLC
Innovative Research of West Florida, Inc.
Clinical Research of West Florida, Inc.
Georgia Institute for Clinical Research, LLC
Atlanta Knee and Shoulder Clinic, PC
Northwest Indiana Center for Clinical Research
Bone Joint and Spine Surgeons, Inc.

results_reference.citation: Wen W, Taber L, Lynch SY, He E, Ripa S. 12-Month safety and effectiveness of once-daily hydrocodone tablets formulated with abuse-deterrent properties in patients with moderate to severe chronic pain. J Opioid Manag. 2015 Jul-Aug;11(4):339-56. doi: 10.5055/jom.2015.0283.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Core study: First subject first visit: 22-July-2011; Last subject last visit: 26-August-2013. Extension period: First subject first visit: 24-April-2013; Last subject last visit of 24-February-2014. The Core and Extension studies were conducted at medical/research sites in the United States.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Subjects with moderate to severe, chronic nonmalignant and non-neuropathic pain.

participants_list.participants: Subjects completing the Core Study were offered an option to enter the 24-week open-label Extension

outcome.title: The Number of Participants With Adverse Events as a Measure of Safety
outcome.description: Safety assessments included AEs, clinical laboratory test results, vital sign measurements, ECG findings, and audiology assessments.
outcome.population: The Core Study safety population (N=922) was defined as the group of subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug during the study. The Extension Period safety population (N=106) was the group of core study safety population subjects who entered the extension period and received at least 1 dose of study drug in the extension period.

outcome.title: Medical Outcomes Study (MOS) Sleep Scale - Revised (MOS Sleep-R)
outcome.description: The MOS Sleep-R is a brief, self-administered 12-item assessment designed to measure key aspects of sleep. It includes a sleep problems index II and 6 subscale scores - sleep disturbance, sleep adequacy, daytime somnolence, snoring, awaken short of breath or with headache, and quantity of sleep. For each individual and time of assessment, quantity of sleep was recorded as the number of hours slept per night. The number of hours it took the subject to fall asleep per night was categorized 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 corresponding to 0 through 15, 16 through 30, 31 through 45, 46 through 60, or more than 60 minutes, respectively. The other scales were recorded as 1 = all of the time, 2 = most of the time, 3 = some of the time, 4 = a little of the time, or 5 = none of the time. A higher value indicates a better score, therefore a positive change from baseline indicates a better sleep pattern and a negative change from baseline indicates a worsening in sleep pattern.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline and up to 52 weeks in the Core Study maintenance period, and up to 24 weeks in the Extension Period
outcome.population: The Core Study population analyzed was the group of subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug during the maintenance period and provided data. The Extension Period safety population was the group of core study safety population subjects who entered the extension and received at least 1 dose of study drug in the extension period.

outcome.title: Brief Pain Inventory Short Form (BPI-SF)
outcome.description: The BPI-SF assessed the severity of pain and interference of pain on daily functions. It consists of 9 sections denoted by Q1 to Q8 and Q9A to Q9G according to their order in the questionnaire, that measure pain location, intensity, pain treatment, and functional interference of pain on mood and every day activities. Scores ranged from 0 (none) to 10 (worst as can be). Four of the items (questions 3 to 6) assess severity of pain and 7 items (questions 9A to 9G) assess interference of pain. The pain interference subscale score was determined by calculating the mean of responses to Q9A - Q9G [Q9A (general activity), Q9B (mood),Q9C (walking), Q9D (working), Q9E (relations with others), Q9F (sleep), and Q9G (enjoyment of life)] and the severity of pain subscale score was determined by calculating the mean of responses to Q3 - Q6 [Q3 (worst pain in last 24 hours), Q4 (least pain in last 24 hours), Q5 (average pain), and Q6 ("pain right now")]. A lower score indicates lower pain.

outcome.population: The Core Study population analyzed was the group of subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug during the maintenance period and provided data. measure.title: Brief Pain Inventory Short Form (BPI-SF)
measure.description: The BPI-SF assessed the severity of pain and interference of pain on daily functions. It consists of 9 sections denoted by Q1 to Q8 and Q9A to Q9G according to their order in the questionnaire, that measure pain location, intensity, pain treatment, and functional interference of pain on mood and every day activities. Scores ranged from 0 (none) to 10 (worst as can be). Four of the items (questions 3 to 6) assess severity of pain and 7 items (questions 9A to 9G) assess interference of pain. The pain interference subscale score was determined by calculating the mean of responses to Q9A - Q9G [Q9A (general activity), Q9B (mood),Q9C (walking), Q9D (working), Q9E (relations with others), Q9F (sleep), and Q9G (enjoyment of life)] and the severity of pain subscale score was determined by calculating the mean of responses to Q3 - Q6 [Q3 (worst pain in last 24 hours), Q4 (least pain in last 24 hours), Q5 (average pain), and Q6 ("pain right now")]. A lower score indicates lower pain.
measure.population: The Core Study population analyzed was the group of subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug during the maintenance period and provided data. class.title: BPI - Severity of Pain Subscale Score

outcome.title: Medical Outcomes Study 36-item Short Form (SF-36)
outcome.description: The SF-36 is a generic health survey with 36 items that measure functional health and well-being from the subject's perspective. The 36 questions are grouped into 11 sections. Some of the sections consist of multiple questions. The survey is summarized into 8 dimensions/scales: physical functioning, role physical, bodily pain, general health, vitality, social functioning, role emotional, and mental health. From the 8 health dimensions, physical component summary, and mental component summary measures are derived. Scores on each scale ranged from 0 to 100; a higher score indicates a better perception of health.
outcome.time_frame: Up to 52 weeks in the Core Study maintenance period, and up to 24 weeks in the Extension Period
outcome.population: The Core Study population analyzed was the group of subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug during the maintenance period and provided data. The Extension Period safety population was the group of core study safety population subjects who entered the extension period and received at least 1 dose of study drug in the extension period.

measure.description: The SF-36 is a generic health survey with 36 items that measure functional health and well-being from the subject's perspective. The 36 questions are grouped into 11 sections. Some of the sections consist of multiple questions. The survey is summarized into 8 dimensions/scales: physical functioning, role physical, bodily pain, general health, vitality, social functioning, role emotional, and mental health. From the 8 health dimensions, physical component summary, and mental component summary measures are derived. Scores on each scale ranged from 0 to 100; a higher score indicates a better perception of health.

outcome.title: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC)
outcome.description: The PGIC is an ordinal scale of global evaluation that assesses the change in overall status relative to the start of the study. The scale has only 1 item that measures global change of overall status (improvement or worsening) by the subject on a 7-point scale (Very much improved, Much improved, Minimally improved, No change, Minimally worse, Much worse, Very much worse.

outcome.population: The Core Study population analyzed was the group of subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug during the study. measure.title: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC)
measure.description: The PGIC is an ordinal scale of global evaluation that assesses the change in overall status relative to the start of the study. The scale has only 1 item that measures global change of overall status (improvement or worsening) by the subject on a 7-point scale (Very much improved, Much improved, Minimally improved, No change, Minimally worse, Much worse, Very much worse.
measure.population: The Core Study population analyzed was the group of subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug during the study. The Extension Period safety population was the group of core study safety population subjects who entered the extension period and received at least 1 dose of study drug in the extension period.

outcome.title: Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire (TSQ) - Part I
outcome.description: The TSQ is a self-administered questionnaire that consists of 2 parts. Part I has 6 questions (Q1 to Q6) that ask the subject to rate the experience with use of the study drug in comparison to the prestudy pain medication regarding ease of use, convenience, frequency, pain control, and overall satisfaction. Each question was rated on a scale from 1 (extremely satisfied) to 6 (extremely dissatisfied): Q1=Satisfaction with study drug; Q2=Ease of study drug use to treat pain; Q3=Convenience of study drug to treat pain; Q4=Overall drug satisfaction managing pain; Q5=Satisfaction with frequency of use; Q6=Ease of planning study drug use. The number of subjects with each category (1-6) of response for each individual question (Q1-Q6) was summarized for subjects who entered the core study maintenance period and responded to each question. TSQ - Part I was not administered in the extension period.
outcome.time_frame: At Week 52 or upon early discontinuation at or before Week 4 in the Core Study maintenance period
outcome.population: The Core Study population analyzed was the group of subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug during the maintenance period and provided data.

measure.title: Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire (TSQ) - Part I
measure.description: The TSQ is a self-administered questionnaire that consists of 2 parts. Part I has 6 questions (Q1 to Q6) that ask the subject to rate the experience with use of the study drug in comparison to the prestudy pain medication regarding ease of use, convenience, frequency, pain control, and overall satisfaction. Each question was rated on a scale from 1 (extremely satisfied) to 6 (extremely dissatisfied): Q1=Satisfaction with study drug; Q2=Ease of study drug use to treat pain; Q3=Convenience of study drug to treat pain; Q4=Overall drug satisfaction managing pain; Q5=Satisfaction with frequency of use; Q6=Ease of planning study drug use. The number of subjects with each category (1-6) of response for each individual question (Q1-Q6) was summarized for subjects who entered the core study maintenance period and responded to each question. TSQ - Part I was not administered in the extension period.

class.title: Q2: Ease of study drug use - extremely easy
Q3: Convenience of study drug-extremely convenient
Q4: Overall drug satisfaction- extremely satisfied
Q6: Ease of planning use - extremely easy

outcome.title: Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire (TSQ) - Part II
outcome.description: The TSQ is a self-administered questionnaire that consists of 2 parts. Part II has 2 questions that measure the subject's willingness to continue the use of study drug as pain medication (Q1), and to recommend the study drug to someone else (Q2). Question 1 consists of 6 categories of response rated on a scale from 1 (very willing to continue) to 6 (very unwilling to continue): 1=Very willing to continue; 2=Willing to continue; 3=Somewhat willing to continue; 4=Somewhat unwilling to continue; 5=Unwilling to continue; 6=Very unwilling to continue. Question 2 consists of 3 categories of response: 1=yes; 2=no; 3=undecided. The number of subjects with each category of response for each individual question was summarized for subjects completing the core study maintenance period and for those enrolled in the extension period.

class.title: Q1:Willingness to continue study drug-very willing
Q2: Recommend study drug for pain - yes

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events (AEs) were reported from start of study participation through the period beyond study completion: up to 84 weeks.
reported_events.desc: AEs were learned of through spontaneous reports and/or subject interview, or observed during physical examinations or other safety assessments. Ongoing AEs were followed until resolution or 30 days after last study drug dose. Serious AEs up to 30 days after last study drug dose or last visit were followed until AE or sequelae resolved/stabilized.

group.title: HYD Core Study
group.description: Hydrocodone bitartrate (HYD) once daily (q24h) tablets Hydrocodone bitartrate q24h film-coated tablets: Hydrocodone bitartrate q24h film-coated tablets 20 – 120 mg once daily

event.description: Outcome: Death. 1 subject experienced 2 serious AEs resulting in death: thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and metabolic acidosis.
Outcome: Death 1 subject experienced 2 serious AEs resulting in death: thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and metabolic acidosis.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
